title: Trump Threatens Columbia With Millions in Cuts Over Antisemitism Claims
abstract: The university, the administration’s first big target in a campaign to root out what it called harassment on campus, could lose more than $50 million in funding.

multimedia.caption: More than a quarter of Columbia’s $6.6 billion in annual operating revenue comes from federal sources.

title: N.Y.C. Council Speaker Attacks Trump in Potential Preview of Mayoral Bid
abstract: In her final State of the City address, Speaker Adrienne Adams, who is considering a run for mayor, proposed ideas that she said could be “scaled for greater impact.”

title: A Plan for Legal Weed Shops Failed. New York Wants Its Money Back.
abstract: The state contributed $50 million to a failed plan to build 150 dispensaries. Gov. Kathy Hochul’s plan to recover the money has stirred concern.

title: Teacher Whose Sex Crime Arrest Shook an N.Y.C. Prep School Pleads Guilty
abstract: Winston Nguyen, who taught math at Saint Ann’s School in Brooklyn, was accused of soliciting lewd images from students. He pleaded guilty to a felony and five misdemeanors.

abstract: At The Times and elsewhere, he wrote about wrongful convictions, fake methadone clinics and the five powerful Mafia families in New York.

title: Day Care Owner Sentenced to 45 Years in Fentanyl Death of 1-Year-Old
abstract: Grei Mendez tried to delete thousands of messages while she was being questioned by police investigators after a child died in her care. Many were recovered, and they were damning.

title: Hal Hirshorn, Artist of Otherworldly Photos and Paintings, Dies at 60
abstract: A ubiquitous presence in New York’s art world, he also existed outside it, using 19th-century techniques to create ethereal, haunting images.

multimedia.caption: A tintype portrait of Hal Hirshorn in 2013. He offered a model for how an artist could live a creative life seemingly unencumbered by monetary concerns.

title: Running for N.Y. Mayor, Cuomo Also Has a Message for National Democrats
abstract: Attacking the Democratic Party’s leadership as he declared his candidacy to run the nation’s largest city, he clearly had a wider audience, and his own ambitions, in mind.

multimedia.caption: Former Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo announced his candidacy for mayor of New York on Saturday, assailing the Democratic Party while trying to rebuild his scandal-hit reputation.

title: M. Paul Friedberg, Landscape Architect Who Celebrated the City, Dies at 93
abstract: He made his mark as a designer of experimental playgrounds in New York City and then used the same ideas to reinvent urban parks across the country.

multimedia.caption: M. Paul Friedberg in 2010 at the Yards Park, a project he designed on the Anacostia River in Washington, D.C. He believed that public spaces were successful only if people used them, and that they should be as inviting and flexible as possible.
multimedia.copyright: Einat Grinbaum/MPFP

title: Cuomo’s First Mayoral Campaign Promise: A Plan to Tackle Affordability

title: N.Y. State Police Investigate Death of Another Inmate at Upstate Prison
abstract: Eleven corrections workers were placed on leave after a 22-year-old inmate at Mid-State Correctional Facility died. Inmates said he was viciously beaten by prison guards.

title: Joseph Gitnig, Central Park Minstrel Known as Pegasus, Dies at 95
abstract: For nearly two decades, he delighted children and adults in New York City with songs and silly antics. He also scored a victory for free speech.

multimedia.caption: Joseph Gitnig, performing as Pegasus, at the Central Park Zoo in 1974. “I’m a poet, writer, actor, dancer,” he once said, “and I put it all together in the package of a clown.”
multimedia.copyright: Cary Azon
